details.content: Graduate Research Assistant, University of Alberta
Conducted quantitative and qualitative analyses of Canadian immigration experiences using advanced digital technology (textual analysis of YouTube comments corpus).
The research team needed a comprehensive, scalable way to analyze large amounts of unstructured textual data to understand immigrants' experiences in Canada from social media platforms.
My responsibility was to explore suitable computational techniques, implement robust analysis methodologies, and draw insightful conclusions from complex data.

Reviewed and selected appropriate digital analysis tools (Voyant, Spyral); Created a structured analytical pipeline for data processing; Conducted qualitative content analysis and statistical evaluations; Documented the insights clearly for dissemination in academic contexts.

Successfully analyzed thousands of YouTube comments, identifying key themes and sentiment trends among immigrants; Enhanced accuracy and depth of immigration-related insights significantly; Improved research efficiency, reducing manual analytical workload by approximately 40%.
Computational text analysis; Quantitative data analysis; Qualitative content analysis; Statistical software usage (Voyant, Spyral); Digital humanities methodologies
Analytical thinking; Problem-solving; Effective communication; Team collaboration; Project management
